entry.title: Re: Character Limit
entry.content: Hi Yilin, The template XML does not have meta-enforce-rte-limit or meta-enforce-plain-text-length-limit configured. For the Section comment, we have set a maximum limit of 8000 characters, and since Section comment is a required field, we also need to set the Item comment limit to 8000 characters, but without making it required.

entry.title: Be the U in SAP 4 U - SAP for Utilities in September
entry.content:
I am looking forward to SAP for Utilities, produced by ASUG, in September in Denver, Colorado.

Source: ASUG

Top reasons to attend:

  1. Community meetups:

Last year we held meetups for Water utilities, Canadian utilities, electric – here’s a look back at what as discussed for Water utilities:

 

We will discuss what you want to discuss.  Take this opportunity to share and learn best practices from your peers.

 

  1. Hear from other utilities, just like yours. 

Discover how leading utilities are embracing cutting-edge technologies to transform and streamline their operations. Learn how SAP innovations are driving business simplification

 

  1. Visit  showcase of SAP solutions tailored for utilities.

Head to the exhibition hall to experience live demos, engage in expert-led discussions, and connect with exhibitors offering cutting-edge technologies, support services, software innovations and hosting options.

 

 

Gather Insights from Customer Stories:

 

  • Hear from Consumers Energy explore their SAP S/4HANA launch playbook—covering everything from internal buy-in and scope alignment to financial and regulatory approvals, team mobilization, and organizational change—based on their journey since May 2024.
  • Join Dominion Energy to explore their SAP S/4HANA EAM journey, highlighting how innovation, metrics, and a growth mindset have fostered organizational change, employee empowerment, and increased solution adoption.
  • Learn from Eversource to hear their CIS transformation enhanced address validation—improving billing accuracy, reducing fraud and safety risks, and ensuring regulatory compliance and efficient service delivery.
  • Join the OGE (Oklahoma Gas and Electric) session “Through the Breach – Security and Compliance in the Shared Responsibility Model” to explore how RISE with SAP delivers transformative technological and procedural advancements that strengthen organizational security and compliance.
  • Attend PG&E (Pacific Gas & Electric) to explore their Clean Core transformation with RISE with SAP—highlighting their shift from a complex legacy ERP to a modern, agile system through fit-to-standard principles, stakeholder alignment, and enterprise design that supports decarbonization, regulatory compliance, and customer-focused innovation.
  • Southern California Edison presents its Next Gen ERP, showcasing how SAP S/4HANA is fueling innovation, advancing sustainability goals, and driving operational excellence—raising business unit maturity to the top quartile of the industry.
  • Southwest Gas features real-world insights as utilities and partners—building on their SAP CX 1.0 successes—collaborate to shape SAP CX 2.0 with forward-looking architecture, increased extensibility, and modern development strategies.
  • DTE Energy shares how integrating SAP CDP with SAP Emarsys is transforming customer engagement by unifying fragmented data, automating processes, and eliminating silos to enhance operational efficiency.
  • PG&E and SAP address the growing complexity of New Load Connections and Electric Generation Interconnections, spotlighting how utilities are streamlining these critical processes amid California’s rapid energy transition and rising customer electrification. (note: first time I recall an important topic like this is discussed at a conference).
  • OG&E (along with fellow SAP Mentor Diego Dora) showcases how generative AI-powered tools helped overcome delivery challenges in their SAP S/4HANA transformation—automating and governing critical lifecycle processes to accelerate results without compromising quality.
  • Eugene Water & Electric Board showcases how their cloud-based SAP S/4HANA implementation is unlocking the Clean Core strategy—enhancing resiliency, automating operations, and optimizing processes across finance, customer service, and meter-to-cash.
  • Discover how Loudoun Water’s Jeff Smith leveraged his experience at Fairfax Water to implement reporting enhancements that increase visibility and improve EAM Master Data
  • UGI Utilities shares how a decade of technology modernization revealed integration challenges that ultimately led to a strategic shift toward a unified financial platform using SAP solutions.
  • Chesapeake Utilities Corporation highlights its transformation of Customer and Field Services by modernizing its Customer Information platform, integrating Florida City Gas, and leveraging RISE with SAP and SAP BTP Enterprise Asset Management to enhance customer experiences and application hosting.
  • Discover how SAP C4C V2 enhancements are tailored for SoCalGas—integrating industry-specific use cases to elevate end-user experience, operational efficiency, and customer engagement.
  • London Hydro shares its end-to-end Greenfield CIS transformation with SAP S/4HANA—focused on modernizing billing through dual contract conversion, streamlining customer communications, and advancing its vision as a digital-first utility in partnership with TCS.
  • Southwest Gas showcases its digital transformation in field operations using SAP BTP, SuccessFactors, and Concur to optimize operational efficiency through automated expense reporting and streamlined training management with QR code-enabled access.

Not a customer session but an important session from SAP:

  • Explore SAP's future-ready service management, where the planned sunset of legacy CS features by 2030 prompts utilities to understand evolving capabilities, retained functions, and new innovations within SAP S/4HANA.

 

Register today: https://events.asug.com/event/SAP-For-Utilities-2025/agenda

Hope to see you in Denver in September.  Do you have any must-see sessions?

My problem in the past was always RAP (not CAP) where i had to use unofficial workarounds like the annotation:

that was replaced by the simplified binding syntax:
https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/releases/archive/2023/jan23#simplified-syntax-for-binding-parameters

RAP only allow bound actions, but you had also to distinguish between:

  • bound actions or functions

    • with context
  • unbound actions or funtions

entry.content:
Hello @paul_gendreau,

do I understand correctly (ref. to the below) that a BP cannot be transferred and created with an IDoc in S4Hana (e.g. scenario when transferring master data from one client to another client, BP Internal numbering and Customer/Supplier External numbering with same number) if there is CVI already in place? Is there a way how to proceed, or bullet two is the way?

  • IDOCs integration in S/4 for creation of Customer/Supplier with same number as BP (Customizing configured as BP Internal numbering and Customer/Supplier External numbering with same number) will not be supported.
  • Creating a BP per Customer and a BP per Vendor is the simple case. Merging related Customer and Vendor into a single BP is more complex and constrained (e.g. SAP Note 2617002 - Legal Entity Check).

entry.title: Re: What features from PP-DS and what differences between...
entry.content:
SAP PP-DS (Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling) is a native module within SAP S/4HANA that offers integrated planning and scheduling based on material availability and finite capacity constraints. It’s well-suited for companies already operating within the SAP ecosystem, offering strong alignment with master data (BOMs, routings), MRP, and execution systems. The system provides tools like heuristics, interactive planning boards, and real-time alerts.

Siemens Opcenter APS (formerly Preactor) is a standalone, highly flexible scheduling solution that supports both finite and infinite capacity planning, with the ability to define complex sequencing rules and simulate “what-if” scenarios. It integrates with any ERP, not just SAP, making it ideal for mixed environments or industries with custom workflows, such as job shops or batch production.

[ES]

SAP PP-DS (Planificación de la Producción y Programación Detallada) es un módulo nativo de SAP S/4HANA que permite planificar considerando restricciones de capacidad y disponibilidad de materiales. Está pensado para empresas que ya utilizan SAP, ofreciendo una integración directa con los datos maestros, el MRP y la ejecución en planta. Incluye herramientas como heurísticas, tableros gráficos y alertas en tiempo real.

Siemens Opcenter APS (anteriormente Preactor) es una solución de planificación avanzada independiente, muy configurable, que permite tanto planificación finita como infinita, reglas de secuenciación personalizadas y simulaciones tipo “what-if”. Es ideal para entornos de fabricación complejos o mixtos, y puede integrarse con cualquier ERP, no solo SAP.

 Hope this helps as an introductory point of view.

entry.title: Supplementary Units of Measure on /ECRS/RP_EDIT receipts report
entry.content:
Please can anyone advise me on Supplementary units of measure?

We receipt a material in KG’s wet and the supplementary unit needs to be its dry weight.

We have been told that the dry weight should be 50% the value of the wet weight.

I have actioned the following however the Receipts Intrastat declaration created via MEIS and then /ECRS/RP_EDIT is not converting the value correctly.

Configuration as per KBA 2782253

 

  1. Map Customs unit of measure to internal unit of measure

 IMG Governance, Risk and Compliance -> International Trade -> Classification -> Define Unit of Measure System > UOM_EU

 Mapping for Customs Unit to internal unit of Measure KGM to KG

 

 

  1. Assign Unit of measure system to Numbering Scheme

 IMG Governance, Risk and Compliance -> International Trade -> Classification -> Commodity Codes -> Define Numbering Scheme Content for commodity code

 

Master data

Commodity code – customs unit assign KGM

Material code assigned to commodity code

Material maser – additional data units of measure 1 KGM = 2KG

 

Sap Notes Implemented

3228475

3197861 prerequisite for 3228475

3203417 prerequisite for 3197861

 

The receipts report shows the same quantity of 200 KG’s for both the supplementary net weight and the net weight.

The system is not using the KG to KGM conversion, have I configured step 1 correctly?

entry.title: Re: Document Generation mapping
entry.content:
Hello,

To get the next month record value in that field you can map future direct option and select that field which will always trigger the future value, but it also has disadvantages:

For Example 
Current date is July 21
There is a future record created for July 22 then in that case it triggers the July 22 value instead of next month so instead of this the best you can do is create a document generation mapping business rule with conditions.

Thank You

entry.title: New Role and Role-Based Permission for Expanded Goal Visibility in SAP SuccessFactors PMGM
entry.content:
In evolving performance management landscape, visibility and flexibility are crucial for HR and talent professionals to drive employee success effectively. SAP SuccessFactors has introduced an exciting new enhancement in the Goal Management module: the Extended EH role, paired with a dedicated Role-Based Permission (RBP). This upgrade broadens access to performance goals, empowering HR leaders and administrators like never before.

What is the Extended EH Role?

Traditionally, access to employee performance goals in SuccessFactors was limited to direct managers and their reporting lines in the organization. The Extended EH role changes this by allowing designated HR users and talent administrators to access performance goals based on flexible target population relationships defined in the RBP framework.

This means access is no longer confined to direct reports but can include broader employee groups based on organizational requirement

EH

Employee's HR representative

Note : The Extended EH role defines designated HR representatives, not confined to direct reporting relationships but determined by any target population relationship defined in the RBP Extended EH for Performance Goals, in addition to existing employee-HR relationships.

Benefits of the Extended EH Role

  • Broader Access Across the Organization: HR leaders gain visibility into employee goals beyond their immediate hierarchy.

  • Flexible Role Assignments: Permission can be assigned per goal plan template, enabling customized access tailored to organizational needs.

  • Improved Talent Management: Greater access supports proactive coaching, better performance reviews, and stronger goal alignment.

How to Configure the Extended EH Role

To enable this feature, ensure your system meets the following prerequisites:

  • The latest Goal Management is enabled.

  • The EH role is configured in your goal plan templates for respective Action permission in each goal plan state based on organizational requirements.

 You can assign the Extended EH for Performance Goals permission through Manage Permission Roles under Administrator Permissions > Manage Goals > Extended EH for Performance Goals.

 

Assign it separately for each goal plan template to control access finely.

Why This Matters

By expanding performance goal visibility beyond direct reports, organizations empower HR and talent administrators with the insights needed to foster employee development at scale. This enhancement helps HR leaders support goal tracking, alignment, and performance management more effectively across diverse teams.

Conclusion:

The introduction of the Extended EH role marks a strategic advancement in SAP SuccessFactors Goal Management, giving HR professionals greater flexibility and control over performance goal visibility. Organizations adopting this feature can expect improved goal oversight, enhanced employee development, and stronger alignment with business objectives.

For further information, refer:

  • 3606219 - Understanding and Managing Extended EH Permissions in Latest Goal Management
  • New Role and Role-Based Permission for Expanded Performance Goal Visibility | SAP Help Portal
  • Roles in Goal Plans | SAP Help Portal

Explore more blogs on SAP SuccessFactors authored by me:

  • Understanding the Current Goal Management Landscap... - SAP Community

  • System Email Notification Status Report - SAP Community
  • Integration Between SAP SuccessFactors and Microso... - SAP Community
  • Configuring Custom Fields to the Country Specific ... - SAP Community
  • Visibility of calculated overall section (Competen... - SAP Community
  • Configuration for Named vs Anonymous visibility of... - SAP Community

Stay tuned for more SuccessFactors tips, updates, and real-world use cases coming soon!

entry.title: 🛒 SAP CPQ + SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 = Seamless Mashup Integration 🧩 for Smarter Selling
entry.content:
SAP has taken a significant step forward by enabling a mashup integration between SAP CPQ (Configure, Price, Quote) and SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, delivering a unified quoting experience directly within the Sales Cloud interface.

What Is Mashup Integration?

Mashup integration refers to embedding one application’s functionality into another, creating a seamless user experience without switching tabs or logging into multiple systems. In this case, SAP CPQ is embedded directly into SAP Sales Cloud V2, allowing sales professionals to create and manage quotes without leaving the CRM environment.

🌟 Key Benefits of the Integration

1. Unified Experience

Sales reps can now access SAP CPQ directly within the Sales Quote section of SAP Sales Cloud V2. No more toggling between tabs or applications—everything happens in one place.

2. Seamless Authentication

Thanks to integration with your identity provider (IdP), users enjoy single sign-on (SSO) capabilities. This means secure, frictionless access to both systems with one login, enhancing security and user convenience.

3. Real-Time Data Sync

Quotes created in SAP CPQ are instantly reflected in SAP Sales Cloud V2 with provided SAP Standard Integrations are enabled in your tenant. This ensures that all stakeholders—from sales to finance—are working with the most up-to-date information.

4. Improved Productivity

By reducing context switching and streamlining workflows, sales teams can focus more on selling and less on navigating systems. This leads to faster quote generation and improved customer responsiveness.

5. Customization and Flexibility

The mashup can be tailored to meet specific business needs, including custom UI elements, workflows, and approval processes—all within the familiar Sales Cloud interface.

🛠️ How It Works

  • Embedded UI: SAP CPQ is embedded as a mashup component in the Sales Quote view.
  • SSO via Identity Provider: Authentication is handled via your existing IdP, ensuring secure and seamless access.
  • Standard Integrations: Quotes, pricing, and configurations flow between systems in real time, powered by SAP’s robust integration framework.

entry.title: Re: Vendor blocked in S4 but External procurement Rel. is...
entry.content:
For information, Core Interface (CIF) transfers PIRs and Source Lists, but it will not automatically deactivate or delete external procurement relationships in PPDS when a vendor is blocked in S/4

If you want to automate this process, explore the below workarounds:-

  1. CIF can be scheduled as a delta transfer job to regularly push the changes. However, Vendor block status is not always part of the standard delta logic. You can enhance the CIF integration model to include vendor status checks and trigger deletion of external procurement relationships.
  2. The other option can be developing a custom ABAP report that reads the blocked vendors from S/4 (LFA1-SPERR), Identifies associated external procurement relationships in PPDS and deletes them for removal. Schedule this as a background job to run daily or weekly depending upon Business critical

entry.title: Re: BUPA_INBOUND_MAIN_SAVE_M09 confirmation back to CI
entry.content:
As you know, IDOC type BUPA_INBOUND_MAIN_SAVE_M09 is designed for Inbound BP creation and not outbound confirmation. It will not automatically generate a response or acknowledgement IDoc as like ALEAUD01 does. So, it cannot be configured to send a confirmation message on its own.

Couple of options are there which you can explore:-

  • Use ALEAUD01 which is the standard way to confirm IDoc processing status. You can configure ALEAUD01 to be triggered automatically via Partner Profile settings via we20.
  • You can create a custom outbound IDoc that sends confirmation back to CI. Trigger it after successful BP creation using BADI_BUPA_CREATE or a workflow event tied to BP creation

entry.title: Re: Returning an SFC in 'Done' Status Back to Its Original Routing in SAP DM
entry.content:
Hi, see 2797822 - Corrections for SAP Digital Manufacturing, Release for latest updates, where it reads:

20/Jul/2025: SAP Digital Manufacturing for execution: SFC Change Production

You can't use production change to move SFCs to or from Special, Nonconformance, or Disposition routings. If user tries to perform Change production to or from special, nonconformance, or disposition routings, user will receive error message "You cannot perform production change for the SFCs having Special, Nonconformance, or Disposition routings."

Br, Manoel

entry.title: 🇩🇪 Build AI services using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and Generative AI Hub
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event is on the topic of Build AI services using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, SAP AI Core and Generative AI Hub. It is beneficial if you have some basic knowledge about JavaScript as we're using the SAP Cloud SDK for AI with the JavaScript variant.

This CodeJam introduces attendees to aspects of exposing generative artificial intelligence (genAI) capabilities to execute tasks using a given business context.

During this event, you'll become acquainted with the theory behind genAI, SAP AI Core, SAP AI Launchpad, and learn how to use the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model to expose AI capabilities through your own OData service.

While working through the exercises, you'll become comfortable creating CDS-based service definitions and integrating them into the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and SAP AI Core Foundation Models.

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Friday September 26th, 2025 in Hamburg, Germany 🇩🇪 from 09:30 am - 03:30 pm. The workshop site will be the SAP office in Hamburg. The event will be held in english.

The instructor is the Developer Advocate @nicoschoenteich.

Prerequisites: Any Chromium-based web browser, such as Google Chrome.

Please note that seating is limited - we can only accomodate 25 attendees. Register here in the Community Event using the RSVP functionality.

For more information on SAP CodeJam events, to ask questions, and to chat with your fellow attendees, head over to the SAP CodeJam group.

entry.title: Comparison between SAP CPI and Mulesoft
entry.content:
Introduction

Mulesoft Anypoint Platform is a middleware platfom acquired by Salesforce. It has been widely used in many industries. On the other hand, SAP has its Integration Suite Platform based on the BTP and it's purely on premise middleware product SAP PI/PO. What are the advantages and disadvantages of SAP middleware products? How do these characteristics impact the project implementation? Which middleware should we choose for a certain project solution? I'd like to make a comparison between them from the following aspects as a developer. The content can be a reference to the architects, or presales. and If you have any other opionions or coents, happy to leave behind. These are the aspects to be compared: 

  • Middleware Product Architecture, on cloud or on premise
  • Centra ERP System
  • Suitable Implementation Methodology
  • API Management Coupling
  • Design and Development
  • Debug tool for Development
  • Logging and Alert
  • Unit Test Tool
  • Mapping technique Complexity
  • Connector Diversity
  • DevOps Supporting Tool
  • Authentication and Authorization

Comparison

  • Middleware Product Architecture, on cloud or on premise

The middleware Mulesoft consists of The Mulesoft Anypoint Studio and Mulesoft Anypoint Platform.

The Mulewoft Anypoint Studio is a local app installed on the local machine. It is the main development tool of Mulesoft.

 

The Mulesoft Anypoint Platform is a cloud based product on the internet. It is the main design tool and runtime tool of Mulesoft.  The development UI is purely browser based. 

SAP Integration Suite is a service within the BTP which is purely on the cloud and web browser based. SAP CPI is the main development tool and SAP API Management is the main design tool. They are different subcomponents inside the integration suite. SAP Integration Suite is on the internet.

SAP PI/PO is a on premise product, which is now, after version 7.31(if my memory is correct) a purely java-based software. It is a server installed locally in the client's intronet. According to current SAP office announcements, it will stop provide support to SAP PI/PO by the end of year 2027. If you are still using the product in your landscape, it is time to look for its substitution now. 

 

  • Centra ERP System

Mulesoft is a product of Salesforce and it has sophisticated connectors for Salesforce operations. Therefore, if your centra ERP system is salesforce, Mulesoft should be the best option of the middleware. While SAP CPI is a SAP product of course, if your centra ERP system is S4HANA or its previous versin ECC, SAP CPI should be the most convenient middleware to be chosen. 

Since Salesforce is a cloud product on the internet, I would say that, SAP CPI still provide a good support to Salesforce as well as long as the relevant service or interface can be easily exposed by means of restful API or SOAP based API. On the other hand, it should be the same convenient for the Mulesoft to integrate with S4HANA on cloud. Whereas if it is S4HANA on premise or on RISE, things become another story. Without the SAP Cloud Connector, all of the interfaces( proxy, idoc, odata) of S4HANA on premise can only be connected once the firewall has been opened up. You probably needs to setup a DMZ(Demilitarized zone) in your network. Anyway it will largely increase the effort of cyber team or basis. This is normally used if the middleware if SAP PI/PO however. Good thing is , it will become a history soon. 

SAP Cloud Connector is a very powerful tool for any SAP on-premise product integration. It is a big advantage to the SAP integration Suite or SAP CPI. 

 

What if the centra ERP system is something other than a SAP product or Salesforce? Please go though the following comparison.

 

  • Suitable Implementation Methodology

According to Mulesoft API lifecycle, we can see that the Mule implementation is highly compatible with the Agile Development Process. 

Both SAP Integration Suite and SAP PI/PO is more suitable for waterflow development process, according to my experience. In some of projects I participated, they used Agile mode for SAP CPI or SAP PI/PO development as well. It has a scrum master, a product owner, a tester and an integration developer in a group and has daily morning standup etc. Whereas I cannot see any benifits of this approach to be honest. 

 

  • API Management Coupling

In the modern age, a middleware product should provide a platform for API Management, including authentication, quota controlling, XML/JSON threat protection etc. This is a limitation of SAP PI/PO, which has no such function. 

Mulesoft Anypoint Platform has a component called API Manager, which provides policy based API management mechnism.

However the process to expose an interface as an API is not very straightforward, it needs some extra configurations in the global configuration of anypoint studio.

For SAP Integration suite, it has an component called API Management. 

It doesn't need any extra steps in the SAP CPI to connect the API proxy. On the other hand, the SAP API Management can retrieve OData v2 metadata from S4 backend directly via the catelog service. The SAP API management is based on APIGee and it is policy based as well. It provides OAuth v2 token generating service which is better than Mulesoft API Management from my feeling.

 

  • Design and Development

 In Mulesoft development, you can design the API by using YAML in the 'design center' of the Anypoint Platform. 

The API document is generated automatically. More intesting is, once the designed content has been uploaded to 'Exchange', the Anypoint Platform can generate the process flow automatically for the Anypoint Studio. The means the development in Mulesoft is closely linked to its design content.

In SAP Integration Suite, the design tool inside the API Management provides a sort of swagger view by using OpenAPI script as below.

Once configured with relevant target URL and proxy URL, it can be connected with any services including any SAP CPI services exposed, or even the OData services from S4 HANA on premise. However the designed API proxy has no direct connection to the CPI iflows developed. In other words, the development of SAP CPI and design of API in the SAP API Management are two separated steps.

 

  • Debug tool for Development

In the Mulesoft Anypoint Studio, you can setup breakpoint inside any steps of a flow. The flow will stop at breakpoint once the endpoint has been triggered. Almost all veriables, message body, headers can be viewed in the debug mode just like debugging a program.

In SAP CPI,  you can set an iflow into 'Trace' mode. 

 

Once done and the iflow has been triggered, the framework stored all message header/body information of each step.

At the same time, SAP CPI provides a simulation tool by which you can test maximum 10 steps of an iflow, excluding any external calls. 

However, you cannot stop the process in form of breakpoint in the SAP CPI. 

 

  • Logging and Alert

Mulesoft provides standard 'Logger' Step for writing any logs to the console. The statement inside Logger is DataWeave-compatible. DataWeave is the Mulesoft embeded script language. 

In the Runtime Manager of the Mulesoft Anypoint Platform, it has the alert repository tool in which the alert can be configured.

Once configured, it can be linked to any application inside the Exchange.

For SAP CPI, there is no native alert step. People normally use the combination of the exception handling process and SMTP receiver adapter to imitate the alert notification. Meanwhile, the SAP BTP provides an alert notification service, which is not straightforward and a bit hard to use in the SAP CPI so far as I know.

BTP alert notification service is not quite convenient to be used for SAP CPI iFlows.

My feeling is the the alert of SAP PI/PO is even better than SAP CPI with regard to the configuration.

 

  • Unit Test Tool

The Mulesoft Anypoint Studio provides MUnit and Munit Tools on the flow level. The component can be used to setup different unit test cases which is suitable for the Agile Development Standard.

SAP CPI has no native unit test tool. The embeded simulation tool can be used to test steps inside and external API test tools like POSTMAN can be used to conduct system integration test. Whereas this is different from the concept of Unit Test and there is no step to check if the outcome is correct or not.

SAP CPI does provide a connectivity test tool which is very handy. It provides a tool to check connection over HTTPS, SMTP, SFTP etc.

 

  • Mapping Technique Complexity

The Mulesoft Anypoint Studio has two main mapping methods:

Graphic Mapping

DataWeave

It has a specific 'Transform Message' step which is for mapping and almost all of the native steps do contain a mapping step inside as well. All of these embedded mapping steps are compatible with DataWeave script. Since DataWeave is the Mulesoft build-in script, it has a relative good performance and provides a powerful functionalily for any different message format including XML, JSON, CSV etc. and the script is similar to the natual language which is not hard to master.

For SAP CPI, it normally supports three different types of Mapping:

Graphical Mapping

XSLT Mapping

Groovy Script Mapping

SAP CPI iflow supports javascript as well. whereas i just do not know that very few cases are using the Javascript as the mapping script. 

For SAP PI/PO, it supports graphical mapping, xslt mapping and java mapping. 

The graphical mapping is normally to beginner which is easy to understand and suitable for relative simple mapping logic. However it is a bit hard to deal with context change. One of the limitation is that it only supports XML message.

The XSLT mapping is the industry standard for XML transformation. For sophisticated developer, it can be used to transform messages into JSON or CSV. However since it is a sort of recursion and declarative language, bad programming skill may impact the overall performance.

The groovy script is the recommended mapping method in SAP CPI. However since it is a open standard programming language, which is lack of any system native performance tuning, any bad programming habit may impact the process performance as well.

 

  • Connector Diversity

For Mulesoft Anypoint Studio, there are hundreds of connectors available, including ones for popular SaaS applications like SAP and Salesforce, cloud services in AWS and Azure, and databases using open protocols like ODBC and JDBC. Furthermore, MuleSoft Exchange offers over 250 out-of-the-box connectors.

Please be aware that , Mulesoft connector for third party systems, like SAP, still needs dll or jar library. like for SAP, it needs jco library. unless the SAP service can be exposed in form of API or SOAP web service. 

For SAP CPI, it is said that there are over 60 pre-built adapters for systems based on different protocols, including SFTP, AMQP, HTTPS, SMTP etc. The integration suite provides a service called Open Connector, which is more flexible for connectivity. However, this service is not free of charge. 

 

  • DevOps Supporting Tool

The Mulesoft Anypoint Platform supports Maven for library updates. It supports GITHUB for content backup and versioning. It can be integrated with Jenkins for CICD.

 

For SAP CPI, it has its native versioning control mechnism for iflow and API proxies. Almost all contents are transportable by using a separated BTP service called Cloud Transportation Management. Since it is purely a cloud based development enviroment, the server maintanance is done by SAP and  is nothing to do with the integration developer. It is said that the CICD can be managed by Jenkins in some tutorials, whereas I have never seen it in any real cases.

 

  • Authentication and Authorization

In the Mulesoft Anypoint Platform, you can define your own business group and its sub group for different landscapes like dev, test, UAT, Production. You provide access to different group by using the roles, which is clear and does make sense.

 

For SAP Integration Suite, the user access consists of nature user access and system user access.

For nature user access, it is controlled by means of role collections. The role connection is a combination of roles in the level of BTP sub account. The BTP sub account is the collection of services or applications, like SAP Integration Suite.

It means, the nature user access control of SAP Integration Suite is NOT inside the service SAP Integration Suite, but the entity one level above.

 

For system user access, it is controlled by means of Service Key configuration, which is in the BTP subaccount as well. Different from the nature user access, it is not using the role collection mechanism. 

The SAP Integration Suite access control is a bit complex and tedious. Good thing is, normally this piece of work is not the task of the integration team, but the security team or basis team. 

For SAP PI/PO, both the system user and nature user are maintained by using the same tool, called SAP Netweaver Admin. At least for me, it is easier to understand compared with SAP CPI. 

Conclusion

SAP PI/PO is out of date product. Though its last version call SAP Process Orchestration, it is not convenient for the integration orchestration, since it is on premise within the corprorate network, which is a bit hard to connect with any services on the internet. and SAP will stop support it in year 2027. So it is time to plan to get rid of it now if you are still using.

SAP CPI is suitable for most of integration requirement and it is purely cloud based. If any SAP system is your centra ERP system, please do not hasitate to choose it, though it is still suitable for any non-system integration, orchestration or work as Enterprise Servie Bus.

Mulesoft is generically suitable for any system integration, especially the project is using the Agile Standard Development Process. It can also be used as the middleware if the centra ERP is a SAP product. However without the BTP Cloud Connector, you might need extra work on firewall configuration. 

If you have experience in either platforms, you are most welcome to leave the comment below for the benifit of readers.

entry.title: Data Services Manager, change DB server name, cannot add in repository, BODI-310079 Already exists
entry.content:
Our SQL servers are being refreshed and the DBAs have created new aliases to connect to the existing servers to make it easier when they switch over to the new ones.  In SAP Data Services Server Manager under the Job Server Properties the server name field is grayed out for editing so I removed the base LREPO_DEV repository and tried to re-add it in using the server alias in the DB Server Name and I am now getting an error stating that the repo already exists, BODI-310079.  The repo no longer shows in the list of existing repositories and I have also removed the section in the DSConfig file located in the D:\SAP BusinessObjects\Data Services\conf\migrated directory.  The DSConfig file in the D:\SAP BusinessObjects\Data Services\conf directory does not contain any repo specific entries.  I was also able to update the server name in the CMC without issue, I just have not deleted the repo from there due to the possible loss of existing DEV work that our dev team has been working on.

Any help on this would be greatly appreciated, I have tried everything I could that I found on this KB and other searches for this error and nothing has helped so far.

entry.title: 🇩🇪 Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event is on the topic of Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core and Python. You do not need to have any background in the topic, but a lot of curiosity!

In this CodeJam you will learn how to use Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core to implement a retrieval augmented generation (RAG) use case to improve the responses of large language models (LLMs) and reduce hallucinations. You will learn how to deploy an LLM and the orchestration service on SAP AI Core and query it via SAP AI Launchpad and the Python SDK. Furthermore, you will learn about the most important genAI concepts and create and use embeddings to improve your RAG response and build your own chatbot with memory.

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Friday September 26th, 2025 at the SAP office in Hamburg, Germany 🇩🇪 from 09:30 - 15:30 local time. The language of the event and the content will be English.

entry.title: Re: Hello, please help.When using the MF in a BOM, the va...
entry.content:
When you switch components in a configurable BOM, SAP re-evaluates the object dependencies and reinitializes the screen context. If the characteristics or values are not persistently stored or linked to the new component, system clears them. This is common when using MFs that span multiple components, SAP does not automatically carry over the configuration

Some workarounds are

  • Define object dependencies (example preconditions or procedures) that retain characteristic values across component switches. This ensures that when a component is changed, the sytem re-applies the correct values.
  • Ensure all components share the same class assignment so that characteristics are consistently available. If a component lacks the class, SAP may not know how to apply the values

Group 2 is one of two possible product categories; let's call them A and B.  So,

  Customer Header

entry.title: Re: GL Balance Discrepancy
entry.content:
Hi,

Cancellation of the Payment will happen on a different date if the user selects the date as "Current System Date" in the system message which appears when cancelling a payment.

In the system message, there are 2 options which appear:

1. Original Document Date.

2. Current System Date.

If the user selects the Original Document Date, then the Payment and its cancellation will be posted on the same date.

For fixing your issue, you need to check if you create a manual JE and it helps or not. The issue with manual JE is that the Payment and its cancellation will be linked to each other so there is just the adjustment which you are going to be making.

Kr,

Jitin

entry.title: Re: How to define possible BOM usage/composition for mate...
entry.content:
Usage type U is flexible and often used as Configurable BOMs, but it does not automatically replicate to usage type M. When a new material is created from a configuration, the system does not copy the BOM to usage M, unless explicitly instructed. As a result CS03 with usage M shows no components, even though they exist under usage U

What you can do is go to cs01 to create a BOM for the newly generated material. Set BOM usage = M. Copy components from the U-BOM or use reference BOM if applicable
Create a reference BOM that links multiple material variants to a single BOM structure. This allows consistent component usage across variants and supports multiple usage types

entry.title: Controlling and Scheduling the Production Using the Work Center Formula Parameter
entry.content:
Business Requirement

Company X wants to determine the duration or cost of operation required to produce a given product depending on factors like work center or tool.  

Company X uses a multiplier called the efficiency factor to the standard execution time, which varies depending on the age of the tools used or weather conditions, etc. They want to execute the process in their SAP Cloud ERP. 

Solution at High Level 

This solution focuses on calculating the execution time of an operation based on the efficiency factor
defined during the creation/updation of production routing. The multiplier that Company X uses is created as a custom field (called YY1_EFF_FACTOR) in Production Routing.

Steps to follow:

1. Access the Custom Fields app from the SAP Fiori launchpad.

2. Choose Add Fields to create a custom field.

3. In the New Field popup, set the Business Context to Manufacturing: Bill of Operations  Operation (PP_BILLOFOPERATIONS_OPERATION)

4. Set the field type to Quantity with Unit, as no other Business context or field types are supported for Work Centre Formula Parameters.

5. Once the required data is entered, choose Create and Edit. 

6. On the  General Information tab, take note of the Field Component Name ending with the suffix ‘_PPO’. This suffix is used to map the custom field to a parameter. 

7. On the User Interfaces tab, enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant SAP GUI screens, CDS Views, and Services. 

8. Enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant business scenario. Enable Routing to Production Order on Operation Level for Discrete Manufacturing.

9. Navigate back to Custom Field work list page.

10. Search for EFF_FACTOR. Select EFF_FACTOR for business context Manufacturing: Order Operation (PP_ORDER_OPERATION).

11. On the User Interfaces tab, enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant SAP GUI screens, CDS Views, and Services.

12. Create a workcenter formula parameter ZPP in the Define Parameters activity (ID: 102242). In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. For more information, see also Configuration Environment of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

13. Create the parameter with origin 8 (Custom Field from Operation). Fill in all the necessary data, leaving the ‘Field Name’ field blank. 

14. Once the parameter is created, create a WKC formula where the SAP standard parameter SAP_01 is multiplied by ZPP to calculate costs in the Define Formulas for Work Centers activity (ID: 102002). In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. 

15. Once the parameter is created and formula defined, map the newly created custom field to Workcenter formula parameter. Use the Mapping Custom Tasklist Operation Fields to Work Center Formula Parameters configuration activity (ID: 106627) to map the fields. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities.

16. Therefore, the creation of the work center formula parameter, definition of the formula, and mapping of the work center parameter to the routing operation custom field are complete.
The next step will be to either create a new work center according to the business scenario or update the existing work center with the newly created work center formula.

17. In the work center, use the newly created work center formula parameter under capacities, scheduling, and costing as per the business need. 

Capacity:

Scheduling:

Costing:

18. For production routing, you can add new operations or update the same operation with a new work center having the newly created work center formula.

Change shown for routing operation 0060:

19. In the custom fields, EFF_FACTOR is visible, and we can enter some efficiency factor into it.

20. Create Production Order for same material.

21. Navigate to Operation Overview.

22. Note the set-up duration.

23. Come back to Routing and change EFF_FACTOR to 20.

24. Schedule the created PO for the same operation. You will notice a change in setup duration due to a change in EFF_FACTOR in the routing.

25. Similarly, in Production Order, change the EFF_FACTOR to 30.

26. Before rescheduling, note the set-up duration.

After reschedule, the duration changes based on the change in EFF_FACTOR.

By following these steps, Company X can effectively streamline its production processes, ensuring efficiency and cost-effectiveness. Embracing SAP Cloud ERP not only enhances operational accuracy but also empowers the company to adapt swiftly to changing conditions.

entry.title: Re: Variant Matching doesn't scrap material flagged for d...
entry.content:
Variant matching checks for characteristic value matches but does not evaluate material status or deletion flags by default. Fields like MSTAE (Cross-Plant Material Status) and LVORM (Deletion Flag) are not part of the standard filtering logic in CU50 or VA01. This means obsolete or flagged materials can still be matched and proposed—even if they’re blocked for sales or marked for deletion.

What you can do is set MSTAE to a status that blocks sales (e.g., status that prevents order entry). This won’t stop variant matching but will prevent selection in VA01, helping in case 2.
In the configuration profile, you can define variant matching strategy to complete configuration only and combine with a custom filter via enhancement to exclude obsolete variants
For any reasons, if enhancement is not feasible, create a custom characteristic like ZOBSOLETE_FLAG, assign value X to obsolete variants, use a precondition or procedure to prevent selection or explode an error when matched. This avoids tampering with valid characteristics and keeps your logic clean.

entry.title: Re: how to integrate SAP Datasphere to SAP CPQ and extrac...
entry.content:
Hello,

SAP CPQ provides API calls for custom tables, which you can potentially leverage to populate a CPQ custom table from Datasphere.

entry.title: Re: Refresh Development System
entry.content:
Hi, Said_Asar_SA

If you would like to refresh your development systems by copying from another system, be extremely careful. In general SAP does not recommend the copy of development systems, because many system specific attributes will be overwritten during the copy and that will lead to inconsistencies after copy. It is possible that your system and ChaRM/QGM project cannot be used after the copy. Consider this before you really perform the system copy.

Nevertheless, if you still would like to make the system copy and take the above risks, you must still close all project cycles where the development system is involved before the system copy takes place. For detail information, please take a look at KBA 2259615.

Please check note : https://me.sap.com/notes/885343/E

Best Regards, Łukasz

entry.title: Re: Session 1 Recap & Highlights– Data Inspired – Successful concepts for data-driven organizati
entry.content:
Thanks @Gaurish-Dessai, I think it's important to take a step back from technology and data detail and think about the broader context. I really like that you started the series from this perspective. 

The instincts or bias that leaders bring to an organisation is a big topic for me. This goes beyond technology and into their broader approach to strategy and transformation. CEOs and CFOs that come from organisations or industries that make a lot of acquisitions tend to want to bring that with them, alternatively leaders from industries like manufacturing tend to bring a strong focus on cost management and P&L optimisation.  Leaders from Financial Services tend to want to optimise the balance sheet. As you said, it can be good and bad.

I often think the cases where it works 'very well' are pure coincidence. I've noted that leaders tend to 'backwards rationalise' their success, this is very common in management books. They try create a 'recipe' after the fact. Which may or may not be the reason for their success or failure. There's often more factors at play than people are aware of.

When it comes to CIOs, the ones that come from organisations that had solid well designed global SAP implementations tend to want to bring that strategy of leveraging well designed ERP for comparability, consistency etc. On the other hands CEOs who come from the organisations that grew quickly through acquisitions tend to be unaware of the real benefits that come with that kind of work. The profile of IT people and leaders in general is quite interesting. It's rarely balanced. Some tend to focus on data, others on solutions, others on skilling up their people, others on micro managing cost, others on interesting innnovation topics.

None of these things are really problems in themselves, the issues come from 'unaware bias' or 'unaware instincts', I think it's important for leaders to understand their motivations and make sure they consider all options / all possibilities when developing strategy.

I think this is quite relevant for enterprise architects too. They are one of the key positions in IT that can bring together the 'right way to do process', 'the right way to do systems', 'the right way to do data', many other roles are stuck in silos.

So yes, this kind of dicussion can open up a lot of interesting dialogue!

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower: Q2 2025 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the first half of 2025, global sustainability governance has entered a new phase of scrutiny and recalibration. The EU Omnibus amendments to the CSRD have postponed timelines and reduced the scope of immediate obligations for thousands of companies, temporarily easing the pressure of compliance. However, this regulatory pause has only sharpened the spotlight on data integrity, preparedness, and strategic ESG integration. 

At the same time, investors, regulators, and civil society are intensifying their expectations. Public disclosures are no longer judged on completeness alone—they must be audit-ready, aligned with recognized frameworks like ESRS and EU Taxonomy. Companies are expected to move beyond box-ticking compliance into continuous ESG performance management, proactively steering their sustainability journey. 

SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) is designed precisely for this challenge. It enables organizations to: 

  • Record ESG factors with out-of-the-box integration to SAP systems and trusted third-party sources 
  • Analyze performance across financial, operational, and sustainability dimensions to support informed decisions 
  • Accelerate the transition through auditable, framework-aligned reporting—covering both regulatory and voluntary disclosures, powered by AI 

Building on our momentum from Q1, this quarter's updates focus on strengthening ESRS-aligned metric coverage, deeper analytical flexibility, improved auditability, and tighter alignment with financial structures. 

 

Expansion of SAP-provided metric coverage   

To support organizations on their ESRS compliance journey, SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) continues to expand its library of SAP-provided metrics aligned with the European Sustainability Reporting Standards. These include both qualitative and quantitative definitions based on EFRAG's implementation guidance. Current metric coverage is available in the SAP Help Portal and detailed in the SAP Community blog, offering transparency and reuse for accelerated implementation.  

 

Looking ahead, we plan to reach approximately 80% coverage of ESRS data points by the end of 2025, including metrics from ESRS 2, S2–S4, G1, and additional quantitative metrics from ESRS Topical Standards. This roadmap aims to enable our customers to progressively adopt SCT content for structured, auditable, and regulation-ready ESG disclosures while maintaining flexibility to extend for sector-specific or company-specific needs. 

 

Analyze ESG Data App Enhancements 

The Analyze ESG Data application now offers a significantly improved analytics experience with the introduction of the Analytics tab. Users can explore all standard custom quantitative metrics in greater depth by applying drill-down dimensions, choosing between chart or table formats, and configuring default views tailored to reporting needs. This new flexibility allows up to three charts to be displayed simultaneously, each with independent metric, period, and structure settings. 

In parallel, users can manage and switch between saved configurations of grouped metric tiles (“Overviews”), enabling different perspectives for different stakeholders or strategic priorities. Together, these enhancements empower users to personalize and streamline how ESG data is analyzed, viewed, and shared – supporting more informed decision-making and stronger alignment with sustainability goals. Find full details here: Using the Analyze ESG Data Application.

 

Custom Templates for “Generate ESG Reports with AI” App 

The Generate ESG Reports with AI app now offers greater flexibility and control through the introduction of custom templates. Users can create or edit templates to tailor the structure and content of ESG reports using available SAP-provided quantitative metrics.  

Within the Templates section, you can now select “Create” to build a new template or modify an existing one by adding sections and subsections, defining narrative text, and selecting from a predefined list of charts and tables. For each component, a content preview is available to ensure alignment with the selected reporting period. Once finalized, templates can be saved and reused, enabling consistent and structured ESG reporting across time periods.  

When generating a report, you can preview or download the result as a PDF—and for added customization, you can edit any section manually. SAP's built-in AI-assistance now supports dynamic revisions: simply select a passage and use the “Revise” option to receive suggestions to shorten or lengthen the text, helping refine your final ESG narrative with ease and speed. 

 

Fiscal Period Support 

The new Manage Fiscal Year Variants app brings flexible fiscal period support to SAP Sustainability Control Tower, allowing customers to define and activate custom fiscal year variants that align with their internal planning cycles. Whether using standard calendar months or granular date-based periods (like semi-monthly ranges), organizations can now tailor their ESG data analysis and reporting across key apps such as Analyze ESG Data, Manage GHG Data, and View Emission Dashboard. Built-in validation checks help ensure data compatibility, with options to consolidate or reimport data when switching to a new variant. This enables more accurate reporting, tighter alignment with financial periods, and greater control over how sustainability data is structured and interpreted across the organization. 

 

Change log updates 

In Q2, we've significantly improved transparency and traceability across SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT). Users can now track create, update, and delete changes to public overview configurations in the Analyze ESG Data app using the View Change Logs app. This functionality extends further, providing detailed logs for changes in business activity data, clearly showing the number of updated or imported records and distinguishing between actual and target data. 

 

New Languages Supported 

To better serve global enterprises, SAP SCT now supports Turkish and Italian languages. This update enables local teams to work in their native languages and enhances cross-regional collaboration on sustainability data collection and reporting. 

 

H2 2025 Roadmap Updates 

Looking ahead, we’re focused on simplifying and harmonizing ESG data consumption and reporting. A key milestone will be the delivery of a unified Read API for metric values – supporting both quantitative and qualitative data – to  make calculated ESG metrics easily accessible to external tools like disclosure management platforms. This API will also expose key metadata (including ESG standard references) and allow for both bulk and individual metric retrieval based on reporting scopes. We’re also working on improving flexibility in data modeling by enabling custom account groups, account-to-group mappings, and supporting activity data input through multiple channels. Additionally, we’ll continue expanding metric-level analysis, measure drilldowns, and export formats in the Analyze ESG data application. To enhance data quality and reporting alignment, we’re introducing tools for guiding data requirements based on double materiality, setting up reporting hierarchies and data sources, and improving transparency on data completeness. In parallel, we aim to deliver ESRS-aligned metric definitions that cover up to 70% of EFRAG's guidance, along with clear documentation and community updates to keep you informed as mentioned above. Stay tuned: SCT Roadmap Explorer. 

 

Additional Information 

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Control Tower, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.
